DESCRIPTION:
This book explores the origins, development, combat use and lasting influence of Nazi GermanyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s automatic rifles, focusing on the Gew 41(W), Gew 43/Kar 43, FG 42 and MP 43/StG 44. The Blitzkrieg campaigns of 1939Ã¢â‚¬â€œ40 convinced many observers that most infantry combat took place at closer ranges than the 750Ã¢â‚¬â€œ1,000m. From 1941 GermanyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s arms designers took note and produced a new series of infantry firearms. The combat takes us from the FG 42 in the hands of Fallschirmjager at Monte Cassino through to StG 44s being used by Waffen-SS soldiers on both the Eastern and Western Fronts. Postwar service is also studied, such as the Gew 43Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s adoption by the Czech Army and the StG 44Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s use by the Viet Cong in the Vietnam War.
